Posts.Content: May 5, 2011 01:13PM LibraryLadyKathy wrote: Hi Kat, This is my first ever posting on a forum, but your experiences have been so similar to mine, I wanted to add my thoughts and hope they help.  I was also diagnosed with both IDC and DCIS following a biopsy (March), that followed an ultrasound (the week before), that followed a routine mammogram (February 2011).  That first inital SHOCK that you might have cancer is life altering, but like you, I got organized and pro-active.  I am "lucky" in that five other women I work with (large school) have gone through this, and I immediately reached out to them for information and advice.  They have been so kind and helpful!  Three used the same surgeon and upon meeting her, I knew she was the one for me.  Following an MRI and PETScan, another "suspicious spot" was seen, so I went for an MRI-guided biopsy.  After trying several times, they were unsuccessful--too deep and small.  SO-I went from thinking I'd have a lumpectomy and radiation to a probable mastectomy with chemo.  I weighed all the options and made one of the hardest decisions of my life--to have a bilateral MX with implants.  I don't want to worry about this coming back for the rest of my life.  My surgery is set for May 17th.  Some days I am calm and almost happier than I was before this started--how weird is that!  Some days I am sad, angry, fearful, numb, anxious.  I struggled with how to tell my family--so hard to tell my kids even though they are grown and on their own (aged 29 and 27).  I am trying to look at this experience as an opportunity to grow and learn more about myself.  I've gotten to know some wonderful women who reach out so generously with their wisdom and best wishes.  But sometimes I feel like a stranger in my own body....  I've been reading this forum for several days, and it has helped a lot!!  Kat, whatever you face, try to not get overwhelmed.  This is manageable, one day at a time.  Best wishes!!
Posts.Title: Feels like a bad dream... kks_rd kks_rd
